cmeta:modification.rdf:value: Updated metadata to conform to the 16/1/02 CellML Metadata 1.0 Specification.

rdf:Description.dc:publisher: The University of Auckland, Bioengineering Research Group

rdf:Description.dc:title: A model of the glycolysis pathway in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae

cmeta:comment.rdf:value: This is the CellML description of Rizzi et al's mathematical model of the glycolysis pathway in the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae (1997). It should be observed that some variables are not fully defined in the CellML model. This is because some parameters were left out of the original paper because of missing sensitivities.

bqs:JournalArticle.dc:title: In Vivo Analysis of Metabolic Dynamics in Saccharomyces cerevisiae: II. Mathematical Model

cmeta:comment.rdf:value: Transport of glucose across the cell membrane occurs via a permease subject to inhibition by G6P.
The phosphorylation of glucose by hexokinase is modeled as a reversible double-substrate, double-product kinetic.
For the following reaction, a near equilibrium is assumed.
The kinetics of the following reaction are based on a four-state allosteric enzyme model, including AMP and ADP as activators and ATP as an inhibitor.
The following rate equation is based on an ordered-uni-bimechanism.

The reaction step RES1 substitutes for the two reactions catalysed by glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and glycerol-1-phosphate. The kinetics of the resulting reaction were simplified by an empirical Hill kinetic.

The reaction RES2 stands for an empirical connection of the enzymes glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPH), phosphoglycerate kinase (PGK), phosphoglycerate mutase (PM) and enolase (EN). The reactions are coupled to the conversion of NAD+ to NADH and production of ATP. These reactions may be combined into a single reaction.
The reaction catalysed by pyruvate kinase is represented by double-substrate, double-product kinetics with a concerted allosteric regulation due to FBP, ATP and PEP.
The rate expression for pyruvate decarboxylase considers a co-operative effect of the substrate pyruvate.
The rate, r_SYNT1 summarizes the several reactions that originate at G6P. Double-substrate kinetics are used and because biosynthetic pathways are involved, an additional ATP consumption is assumed.
Alcohol dehydrogenase is modeled with double-substrate kinetics.
The enzyme acetaldehyde dehydrogenase shows substrate inhibition kinetics.
The adenylate kinase reaction allows the production of ADP from AMP and ATP and has been modeled with a near-equilibrium reaction.
The rate equation for the triose phosphate isomerase is a reversible Michaelis-Menten kinetic.

The exchange of adenine nucleotides across the mitochondrial membrane (translocation) is essential for the dynamic analysis of the yeast under aerobic growth conditions. The translocation of adenine nucleotides has not been studied in yeast cells. The equations below are based on studies using rat liver cells. Unsymmetrical and uncoupled translocation following two irreversible Michaelis-Menten kinetics. AMP exchange is not possible.
ATP demand for growth is summarized in the rate equation below.
The kinetic expression for pyruvate dehydrogenase assumes ping-pong kinetics with two substrates and one product.
